review_title: Join TSMC if you like challenges and self-growth in your career
pros: I’ve been working for TSMC for about one year now. There are pros and cons here like any other company. My first impression after three months at TSMC was feeling challenged but fulfilled. All challenges forced me to learn and understand the diversity in this company. I don't necessarily agree with the work culture 100% but I do respect the challenge that TSMC is facing in establishing a Fab in a foreign country from the ground up. If you like challenges and self-growth, TSMC will provide you with that in your career path plus great compensation and benefits.
cons: There were many unexpected tasks and responsibilities that popped up during my training in Taiwan. Luckily, I had great team support from both Taiwanese and my current teammates.

review_title: Proud to work for the most advanced semi company
pros: 1. Compensation: Great salary and bonuses. TSMC provides above-market pay (more than other semi-companies) for most of its employees including technicians, engineers, and managers. The relocation package they provided was over-the-top generous and really helped me settle into the greater Phoenix area 2. Corporate culture: feedback-heavy culture but emphasized commitment, low-key, and pursuit of excellence. It took me a little bit to get used to the "continuous improvement" culture of TSMC as you will always get more feedback than compliments in this company. It can be mentally tough in the beginning but will eventually build your character and force you to be the best version of your professional self. Commitment-wise, TSMC really emphasizes the value of keeping you word to your clients, suppliers, managers, and subordinates. This means going above and beyond for everything you promised to turn in. This can be very stressful at times but i grew tremendously under this corporate culture. Low-key, TSMC values humbleness and having a low-key attitude. Though with the good compensation, some of its entry-level employees and first-line manager can be seen as show-offs at times; the majority of management and senior leaders are humble and down-to-earth people that truly value integrity and doing the right thing. This also means giving out zero to nothing of press releases about any contribution TSMC provided. Lastly, the pursuit of excellence. This is very similar to the feedback culture, TSMC brings out the best of you by always chasing after excellence. From product quality, wafer yield, to any deliverable you have to hand in; this company asks you to turn in the best version possible. In all honestly, I believe that's what put TSMC above its competitors and what will help to continue its leadership. 3. Work & Career: being the most advanced semi-company and getting to work with the top silicon valley clients, like Apple, AMD, and Nvidia, all at once brings me excitement when going to work. Knowing that I am playing with the most advanced technology ever existed also challenges me to do better. No matter the scope of my job, I am constantly working with different equipment engineers, process engineers, and sometimes facility engineers to resolve probably the world's toughest problem.
cons: 1. It is NOT EASY for a Taiwanese company (non-American companies) to build the most-advanced Fab with the largest capacity in the States. There is quite some work to be done to merge the two cultures. HR has already done a lot of professional development but you still see cultural clashes when working here. Taiwanese are not used to the innovative, work-smart-not-hard American working styles while American find Taiwanese can be condescending at times. These simply come from a lack of understanding of each other and differences in cultures of communication; both sides simply want to do well and achieve more (but simply using a different method) 2. Company sometimes gives more tolerance to senior employees who are out of time and incompetent. Keep them at their job simply for their seniority even though some can be useless. 3. Work-life balance. This is not just referring to work hours or work intensity. This means Taiwanese are used to making work a major portion of their lives, aka your friends are mostly work friends and you engage with your superior more in your downtime.

pros: Good pay in Taiwan. Advanced materials and state of the art manufacturing knowledge.
cons: Hardly work life balance. Bad user-Interface of system. Badly management skill. Not kind for employees

pros:
Was able to train in Taiwan, work for one of the most important companies on the planet that no one knows about, be exposed to culture outside the US, am being given skills I can take to lot's of desirable positions in the future.

There are incompatibilities between work culture, learning/teaching style and other expectations from the US to Taiwan. This is to be expected. My trainer I think has definitely met me part way, and I believe I can say I have done the same. There's still a gap, but this can be worked on.
cons:
The work culture in Taiwan is really different than in the US. I am sure TSMC will have to change to an 8 hour work day five days a week or do what other companies do with Fabs and run three days on, four days off, four days on, three days off rotations. As it is right now in Taiwan The minimum amount of time at the company is 10 hours a day, but realistically is running up to even 12 hours a day. This is for those of us who are American training to go back to the new operation in Arizona. The reality for people from Taiwan is that they are doing even more than 12 hour days often. There's also the night shifts and weekend shifts on duty and/or on call. That last part is understandable as the fab lives 24/7.

The training in this experience really depends on one person who is your "trainer". My experience has lacked any structure, but had no shortage of expectations. I came up with some process to approach learning new equipment and daily tasks, but to be honest don't know that I've arrived yet.

TSMC doesn't seem to enshrine a sense of individual freedom. The company provides housing for those of us training from the states, but has very much micromanaged everything we do in our living arrangement. There's a curfew with no guests allowed for example. And the long term housing adds another hand hour commute.

review_title: World leader but as such comes with a tradeoff
pros:
World's undisputed manufacturing leader of leading edge silicon. 

Growing like crazy so opportunities for learning and growth are limitless. 

Come if you love solving problems and making what makes all the devices in the world go!
cons:
Hours are long, doesn't matter what function and especially in TD or leading edge fab expect it. After seeing this in multiple companies and countries the hours here aren't longer than anywhere else. Come if you want to do similar hours, but be at the winner! 

The culture is hierarchical, extremely disciplined, and focused. The business drives fast daily pace and relentless focus on continuous improvement and innovation. Some would like to say it is Far East or Taiwanese. I'd say it is TSMC unique as it is company specific that has resulted in competitive edge and world wide domination. Certainly not for everyone, nothing comes without a tradeoff.

pros: Salary in Taiwan is good.
cons: Work more than 12 hours a day.

pros:
The company has tried harder recently to offer competitive wages and aim to be one of the highest paying companies in the industry. Decent benefits. Opportunity to travel to Taiwan for training. They overvalue education here (pro if you have a higher degree, con if you don’t). So if you have a PhD, this place will definitely overpay you for it and you start as a principal engineer. 

The Taiwanese coworkers are great and I have made many life-long friends. The issues that I have with the company are with how the company is structured, and company culture, not necessarily with the people who work there.
cons:
Let me start by saying that I was with the first batch of engineers that flew to Taiwan to be trained in advanced semiconductor technology so that we could then help open the fab in AZ. There is a large list of things to be critical of but I think the biggest issue is that there is no plan. From the beginning, it was clear that the company had no plan for what to do with us. We arrived and no critical document was in English (including basic SOPs or other instructions necessary to perform our job functions). So, they told us that we need to translate everything ourselves (although speaking Chinese was not a job requirement). As you might suspect, Google Translate is not the most effective tool when trying to translate important documents. I have been in Taiwan for over 14 months now and they still have yet to translate everything into English. Upon arrival, we also discovered that there really is no permanent seating for us. They didn’t even try to set up a temporary spot for us. We kind of just had to squeeze between multiple of our colleagues and fight for space on a shared desk which is not equipped with any ergonomic equipment. Multiple people have already started complaining about neck, back, and wrist pain due to the poor seating arrangement. They try to integrate us into the Taiwan Fab, but it is near impossible with the language barrier. They make it very difficult for us to have access to the systems needed to do our jobs. To this day, I still don't have access to most critical systems that I need in order to perform my work. Our training is mostly dependent on what trainer we got. But most are too busy to actually train us. 

HR has admitted that they have very few actual company policies. This has led to them either deferring to Taiwan HR policies or just flat out making up policies on an employee by employee basis. The relocation package to Taiwan is absolutely horrific compared to what any other American company would provide and in many cases they misrepresented what the benefits were before we arrived in Taiwan. They only provide transporation to the fab during certain times during the day. We constantly have to beg just for them to pay for transportation to/from work if we have to take a half day or sick day. They stated that they only pay for a taxi for us to go home if we already worked longer than 12 hours that day (not to mention our housing is 1 hour away from the office so they are really asking for a 14-hour day). They make up covid policies on the spot and have kicked random people out of their housing if they get covid (and then a few weeks later will change the policy and try to hide it). They attempted to control our lives outside of work by controlling what other employees we can and cannot see (when there were only a few covid cases in the entire country). Our housing isn’t equipped with drinkable water nor dryers in each unit. The housing that they showed us before we moved to Taiwan looked nothing like the housing we actually moved into. They didn’t tell us until a year in that all tsmc rules at work also apply to our housing (they still have yet to officially admit that, presumably so that they can change rules as they see fit). They do not own the housing that we stay in and have yet to tell us why they are able to make up these random rules for our housing. For those that haven't been to Taiwan, understand that tsmc has so much influence that they can pretty much convince the landlords to follow any rules they set. I understand that living conditions are different here than in the US, but when you are asking employees and their families to upend their entire lives and move to another country for 2 years, you should at least try to make it appealing. An attempt has not even been made. 

Everything here is highly disorganized. There is very little documentation which makes it hard to replicate certain tasks (which would normally be pretty easy to replicate). Otherwise easy tasks turn into multiple hours of tracking down the right person who knows this specific information who then tells you to reach out to this person who is busy in a meeting so waiting another 1-2 hours before finally getting an answer and moving onto the next step. Over the course of my time here, I have already had 2 directors, 3 department managers, 4 section managers, and various other mid-level bosses. No entity on earth can function properly when there is this much management constantly changing and being moved around. 

I haven’t heard one Taiwanese employee say they like working here. Even my first week here I would ask some of my colleagues and they were very open about not liking it here.

CEO said in a motivational speech: do you know what does an exempt emoyee mean? It means that you're exempt from labor laws, that's his take on it. When he was asked how do we acheive work/life balance? His answer was work hard, play hard, how does he expect his employees to play hard when work hard means working from 8am and staying until 8-10pm everyday, sometimes 6 days a week if you have a weekend shift? Now the problem is that this is the CEO take on things, and it resonates through the hierarchy of management until it reaches the employees, so imagine how the work culture is like. 
People get threatened with their bonuses for literally everything, it's their way of retaliation. You do whatever you're told to the way THEY expect you to do it, never object anything or say a word, or you get a huge pay cuts.

pros:
+ I work with really cool people.
+ Many people were hired who would not have otherwise been offered similar positions in the industry. This is because the extensive training period in Tainan lowered the barrier to entry.
+ Taiwan is a beautiful country, and I am greatly appreciative of the time I have to explore it.
cons:
- Wages: Employees at this company are underpaid relative to positions elsewhere in the industry. Taiwanese hires especially get the short end of the stick when it comes to salary, many getting paid less than half of their American-born counterparts in the same role. On top of this, TSMC overvalues degrees, and severely undervalues experience when determining wages. 

- Advancement: Management positions are reportedly not given to those without a masters degree, regardless of fit. some managers claim the benefits to Fab 21 is its opportunity for promotion, but others explain that promotion is unlikely.

- Training Program: Often, trainings were hampered by Covid-19 in-person limitations and overloaded trainers. Local experienced engineers were not given a reduced workload to allow for time to build the training program, instead it was an additional task to be done in parallel. In addition, the trainees were often made to feel like the training was a barrier to navigate when completing their assigned tasks, resulting in minimal effort on both sides.

- Work Culture: Projects are often adversarial, rather than cooperative, racing on tasks to claim credit. It is not uncommon to discover multiple other individuals were working on your project in parallel after the fact. Employees very often have tasks stolen from them without their knowledge, wasting their time and losing their credit. 

Interdepartmental relations are especially adversarial. The roles of Manufacturing, Integration, Yield, and Module are inherently antagonistic to each other by design. Information is often withheld and obfuscated, and communication is ignored. The excuse often given is IP, but the truth is the more you share, the more the other department will use against you in the future.

Regarding management, it often feels like most of the friendliness and offers for help can be lip service. I have observed coworkers bringing complaints to management regarding work-related health issues, obstinate teammates, and overloading that were not fully addressed, and sometimes shrugged off. Employees are often left to sort out their own problems.

- Work/Life Balance: Early on during my stay in Taiwan, there was a presentation in which someone told us that, "It is not about balancing work and life, its about finding a way to live through your work." This about sums it up, as the hours prohibit you from living anywhere other than inside the Fab. I cannot stress to you enough how brutal the work/life balance is here. 
I know people who slept in the office for a month straight. 12 hour days are standard, weekend shifts are common. Many locals come in on the weekends even when they're not scheduled, just to catch up on the work that their 60+ hours that week could not cover. TSMC provided its AZ hires lodging during their "training" stay, but failed to mention during the interview process that it would be an hour commute. This turns 60+ hours of work into 70 hours of time sunk into the company.
Even meals are often not sacred, It is stressed to employees that they are not to eat away from their desk, and that they are not to talk to each other during meals, under threat of lower performance reviews. 
It is common to receive work calls in the middle of the night, or 6am on the weekends, and so even when you leave the company, you must keep your phone with you at all times.

- Human Resources: Understandably, they work on behalf of the company. Less understandably, it seems that they work against the employees. Policies change on email by email bases and differ by sender, recipient, and hiring date. Important information is often danced around with vague and indirect language that leaves many in the dark, and requests for transparent baseline policies are met with directions to send an email that will be ignored. one incident like this can be forgiven, a few can be seen as incompetence, but operation to this degree feels almost malicious. Part of the strain with HR is a result of their high turnover, causing remaining employees to be overloaded and have less patience. 

A few months into our stay, HR pushed us to sign a document saying we would pay the company roughly $20k USD. They claimed this was to "prevent us from paying taxes any differently than we would in the States," regardless of the fact that this payment was not to the government. When resisted, they attempted to claim it was mandatory. We had multiple info sessions with contracted accountants in which they would explain how most of us would definitely lose money to TSMC by signing the form, but TSMC still recommended it. We were told the money would help "compensate TSMC for training expenses." Many trainees preferred to give HR the benefit of the doubt until this point.

Overall, I'm incredibly disheartened. I was very excited to learn about the cutting edge technology we create here, and I really have met some terrific coworkers. The hardest part has been seeing all those friends lose excitement alongside me.

review_title: Good at what they are producing; terrible environment
pros: Good in the field of semiconductor, known for low yield rate and production productivity. This is my 13th years working at semiconductors industry and after training in Taiwan for over 1.5 years and engaging with people locally in F18, I have extremely upset on the management style within the organization.
cons:
After some honest reviews being posted by a few engineers who traveled oversea to Taiwan for training; I expect the leadership hear that and implement changes so that we can retain those talented engineers we spent months of effort to hire. However, instead, I am now hearing a lot of defense from Taiwanese leadership saying that this brutal management style is what they become the best of the best, and people who leave just not capable of such task. I even heard some managers told engineers that you are spending long hours in the office just like other competitors BUT working on something better…one thing that TSMC really stood out in this game is purely because Taiwanese engineers work extremely hard to fulfill the household needs in Taiwan. From my point of view, the success is not driven by problem solving mindset, learning attitude, or fast pace environment; the success is mostly because Taiwan probably has one of the most disciplined engineers in the world that barely share their thoughts when they disagree on something or feel something isn’t done right, and this is the culture difference that people in Taiwan need to accept. Being proud of such culture will only make the way to US harder, believe it or not.

Perhaps TSMC in Taiwan is one of the best so they never really think about themselves when it comes to employee retention, but they forgot that there are tons of companies here in the US just as good and big revenue wise as TSMC. 

I understand it’s manufacturing, there’s certain level of discipline needs to be in place but again I am not talking about the hours, I am talking about the mindset, the leadership mindset of adopting new culture.

review_title: Working in CIM is like in hell
pros: $$$$$$. They can only put your money in front of you, but it might less if you're good enough.
cons:
1. Managers don’t know the software and don’t understand how the program works properly
2. No development chance for engineers to learn the new technology and to improve the efficiency for work
3. No career plan for engineers to help engineer grow, there are only many ARs (action requests) to ask engineers work very hard to fulfill the requirements from users.
4. Managers don’t care your life, they only care their reputation and their performance in the higher management. They even ask engineers to work very late to deliver what they want.
5. Still use Delphi 7 (yes, Delphi 7 not the 8 or 200X or XE or 10.) which should be retired in the present day for the reports and agents.
6. Very unstable middleware to the database. It’s written in Delphi 7 with DCOM. I don’t know how to criticize this point, it is very unbelievable to happen in a “software department”. Nowadays, it should be something written in Java, C# or Go. Even Python might be faster and stabler than Delphi 7.
7. Every project came and sunset soon once it got credits, they claim they resolve a lot of issues happening in the factory, but it won’t last too long because people need to accomplish another thing before the next performance evaluation, so their best strategy is to sunset the system they just delivered.
8. Although it’s CIM, the “data science” team is the most comfortable team to stay because they don’t need to be on-call and to own the programs which may cause issues for the products. Plus, they usually have good performance because their work can highlight people to do and make actual credit from that.
9. Don’t have system design meeting, code review and endorsement meeting for publish as a software department. Instead, you need to have a lot of signatures/approvals from users and managers to let you publish new programs on the production environment. Once issues happen, managers only care the impact scope and ask you fix it ASAP. They don’t want to be responsible for your work.
10. Engineers in CIM need to be multiple roles i the same time. You need to be RD, QA, DevOps and PM by yourself because managers don’t show up in the meeting with users and you need to face them by yourself. They are only aware of that you’re doing some projects when users are requesting something.
11. Unbalanced workloads between engineers. Performant engineers usually have a lot of applications to own. That is, you need to work from 8 to 22 to have meetings, tracing bugs and developing something new. However, the engineers with lower productivity or high chance to make mistakes don’t get work. They can just go office at 8:30 and leave the office at 17:30. In total, bad money drive out good.
12. Sometimes, you may find the CIM managers just a person with mouth and no any real know-how to guide you and help you in the work. They act like emotional animals to ask you do anything they want. For example, one manager don't know how the function works in their project with the energy statistics or Docker, but he always ask people to use these 2 things to complete projects, then he can get the credit.
13. Engineers need to share machines instead of having a PC for your own.
14. Good engineers are leaving one by one, and there are almost no good engineers leaving.

review_title: Relatively high year-package and solid market share of the company, ant that's all.
pros:
1. Generally  and relatively high year-package in Taiwan for almost all positions, especially in southern Taiwan.

2. Solid market share of the company, hence the job is quite stable in the long term.

3. Accept people from many fields with many kinds of position.
cons:
1. The package looks big, but the pay is very low. Most of the package comes from the quarter bonus, which means the package has the strong correlation with the performance of the company at that year.

2. Disastrous work-life balance. Overtime working, full time standby, and holiday working is not only common but also continue for a very long time.

3. Slow learning curve of professional knowledge for each single field unless principal engineer level or higher.

4. Closed culture and knowledge(especially for system level). It take you a lot to learn these internal systems, but it almost left you nothing when you step out the lobby.

pros: high salary and good benefits

pros: Comp is ok, but lags other large companies in the US.
cons:
Taiwanese style management is broken.  Poor working environment.  Cramming into an elevator with 20 other people in the morning.  Cafeteria food that makes you sick every day.  No parking if you don't get there by 7:30AM (nice way for the company to get you to come in early).  You don't get to use your vacation days.

This entire system is broken.  You should not come to TSMC if you have a decent job working in the states. I wouldn't recommend this place to my worst enemy.  And also, they work hard to make sure that you can't leave the job (play interference with potential employers, cancel any days off so you can't go interview, etc).

pros:
1. Opportunity of learning  the cutting edge Si manufacturing technology
2. Relative high compensation compared with other companies in Taiwan
3. Be able to work in a leading company in a growing industry
cons:
1. The average working hour is too long and highly unbalanced. The working hour in some of the FAB departments is definitely in violation of regulation under authorities.
2. Employees put too much focus on KPI reviews, regardless of the formation of business culture.
3. The deadline of project is always so tight that there's insufficient time for team members to make their judgment. Those who couldn't meet the target deadline were usually punished by PMD reviews and be forced to transfer to other department, while the successors take all the benefit once the projects delivered.  
4.Many of the employees are abused verbally by their supervisor on a daily basis, and the atmosphere in the office is highly uncomfortable.

review_title: No work life balance, good pay in Taiwan though
pros:
1. Compared to most other companies in Taiwan the pay is good.
2. Leading technology if work in R&D department
3. You can learn a lot if you want to.
cons:
1. No work life balance. At least 12hour a day. Frequently work during weekend.
2. High pressure. Everything has to be done really quickly. Schedule delayed is not acceptable. Any kind of mistake is not allowed. 
3. Poor management. Most of the managers do not know how to manage. They just blame your work and criticize till they are happy. Minimum guidance and ask you to do a lot of work in very limited time.
4. Bad culture. A lot of people work only for theirselves. Full of selfish people. Especially management class. They only care about their career.

pros: good salary comparing to most company in Taiwan, benefits also outstanding. Boss always ask you to have vacation as much as possible....
cons: too much work, work-life balance isn't easy, routine job, not creative at all. Training at the beginning isn't enough, always saying like this: Learn when you are doing your job. The profession that you learn from company isn't easily allied to job in other company, unless you go to another semiconductor company.

review_title: Good pay in Taiwan but working under high pressure
pros:
You can learn a lot if your mindset is positive, humble to learn and ask. There are many many things you can learn from other departments.
The benefits is not bad. You don't have to be in front of your seat in the day, you can walk away, discuss with others, and drink coffee.
There are still some good supervisors.
cons:
Normally you will have several projects which make you feel nervous to give weekly update .
The Manufacturing is the most powerful unit, so you have to solve the production issue as soon as you can, otherwise, every body would call you. It's high pressure.
Some supervisors don't help you too much but request you to do many things, and don't care about your time/working priority.

review_title: Good places to learn a lot in R&D units, not good in Fab
pros:
There are many talented/experienced people working together to solve the process/integration issues, although some integration engineers cannot decide which approach is better, they want all tries, and that make the process engineers exhausted.
There are also some efficient utilities to assist engineers to dig out the useful data to troubleshoot. IT support are great.
Salaries+bonus is much better than other companies in Taiwan (although not comparable to the big ones in US)
cons:
Too many trivial rules and unreasonably tight specs to follow, and that induces engineers make the fake data in order to pass the tool releasing to the manufacture.
Most Fab engineers do the routine, trivial, and boring works every day.
Poor work-life balance for most positions(especially Fab positions), but it depends on which role you're playing.

review_title: TSMC RD technology skills are very strong , especaily in advenced technology nodes with HKMG & FINFET process.
pros: TSMC RD has very good organization function design to develop many different tecnnology nodes in parallel. 10 years there are only two platforms in RD organization to develop two generations technology nodes in paraellel,  In the last  5 years , TSMC RD organization was redesign by module process function , not by tecnhology node. So new RD organization is  well designed to develop 4  different tecnhology nodes in  parallel .
cons: To delivery mature technology to market on schedule or even ahead schedule, the job loading and stress is quite big for their engineers & managers.

job_title: Software Engineer in Union City, CA
pros: TSMC is a international large company, and also one of the most outstanding giant of the semiconductor business. TSMC always follow with the newest technology. Not only the employers also the employees have enthusiasm to work to make the company stronger.
cons:
Project manager/coordinator of systems/database migration project and proposed comprehensive IT solutions to re-engineer system architecture for minimizing database (oracle/DB2) loading and enhance system performance.
Directed software programming and modified existing software to solve user problems and support FAB operation.
Enabled equipment automation and developed several tool automation programs/functions (VB.NET/C/C++/C#/Java) to save manual handling resource and prevent miss operation.

pros:
Though TSMC is a foundry but the office and working environment are pretty friendly.
1. The package is competitive 
2. The employee's welfare is good with quality food, gym, and coffee shop in the rest area.
3. The overtime is paid.
cons:
1. Most of the jobs need to work in morning and night shifts, even you are an senior engineer.
2. Lack of flexibility in the working environment. Most of time, you work by using software and PC to control the system.
3. Lack of life and work balance.

pros:
- Big company, with high diversity. To meet different people is interesting.  One can grow very fast by learning other colleague's advantage.
- Form action plan for issue and assign due date for sponsor, very effective management culture.
cons:
- Environment was too complex (too much things to know) where managers often had no time/patience to listen details. First thing they do ask is how much "benefit" ? 
- managers are always right.
- Growing from a big company to even bigger company. Promotion is not easy.
- Delay 1/2 bonus delivery until mid next year ( new employee: 1st 3 months in company are considered as probation, no bonus ).

review_title: Come if you are old enough and just waiting for your retirement
job_title: Technical Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Good medical insurance plan and stable job
cons:
1. Hardwork are not recognized since the big bosses are in Taiwan. 
2. HR keep lying about good bonus and salary progression. Then you join and realize it's not just lower than what they said, but SUBSTANTIALLY lower. And later you find out HR here is so powerful that your boss can't even help you with a more reasonable pay. 
3. Hours are long considering the poor salary. There are lots of meetings till night with the Taiwan people

review_title: A stable and large company, but working hours could be long.
pros:
(1) This is a very large company and has many different kinds of jobs. You could learn things in many different departments.  
(2) Very stable company. You won't be lay off until you do something terribly wrong.
cons:
(1) The working hours could be very long sometimes for an engineer. Average working hours is 8:30 till 20:00~21:00. When obnormal things happen in the Fab, you might need to work till 23:00 for 2 or more weeks.  
(2) After mid 2008, the stock bonus is cut to 60% of the past. But working hours won't change.

review_title: If u r a man with self-respect, dont join tsmc
pros: one of the best companies in terms of job security. A normal/low level of knowledge is enough to get a job in tsmc, but you need to have good university degree.
cons:
work hours are too long. 
Appraisal and career growth is not transparent. 
The culture is like the employee should do whatever the manager gives. Even if everyone knows that its non-sense, you just need to do it. 
When the company is in loss, they will cut employee salaries. But, when company is in higher profits, they will not give any extra profit sharing bonus.

pros:
To be with family in Taiwan.
People in Taiwan admire you when you are working in TSMC.
The company won't fire people for now, so your job is stable and secured.
The job is easy and routine, which leads to good life-work balance if your manager is not mean.
cons:
Salary is really low compared to big companies in the US.
Not much career growth opportunities.
Living is not easy in Hsinchu since the salary is only half of what you will get in the US, but the living cost is similar to San Jose.
The environment and traffic is terrible in Hsinchu as well.

review_title: Salary, Good; Work-Life balance, could be better
pros: It's hard to find a job for a fresh graduated person with that salary like tsmc. You can talk to people not just you manager and colleagues, but also the vendors.
cons: Works in tsmc is just like works in other big company. Although a equipment engineer, especially junior level, is hardly to contact any political issue, but the rules fill into every corner in your life. Good and bad. If you would like to have job with more individuality, not here. People here are afraid of making mistake, so they try less than they wish.

review_title: The professional foundry manager for R&D department.
pros: The engineers' quality and sense of semiconductor area are very strong and most engineers are proactive and willing to learn new things. It is very comfortable to be a manager or technical leader to lead the project.
cons: The job loading and stress are very high for a manager level to handle a project. The endless job assignments are always coming to your desk, no matter day or night. There is very few time to consider other things, such as family, friends and social relationship.

pros: This is a efficient company. If you face some problems, you always should follow the SOP to deal with it. If there is no SOP, you should build one. You can learn a lot of methods to solve problem systematically.
cons: Some of the analysis tools are out of date. For example, if you use python/R to analyze the device experiment data, you probably can finish the report (including figure, table, outlier, mean/median.. etc) in 10 mins; however, the tools you have are excel and SAS. Thus, if you familiar with these tools, you still must spend at least one or two hours to finish your report.

pros: When I rate my work at TSMC, am particularly referring to my group headed by a foriengner who is one of the top most person in the field as well as the first fellow (highest academic title in a company) of the company. Since I work directly with this person as my boss, my work at TSMC has raised my academic, professional as well as my technical standards which am glad it came at an early stage of my career.
cons: Language could be an issue if working in a group thats not headed by a forienger.

review_title: Great Job if you don't need to go out
pros: Amazing if you love to learn. Plenty of activities (clubs, events) within the Company. Great fellow engineers and a great place to learn.
cons: No work-life balance (12+ hours and weekends). Your work load will highly dependent on how skilled your manager is. Must have phone at all times. High pressure. Know Chinese.

pros:
Good benefits and competitive annual package in Taiwan
This is a good place for freshman to learn the attitude and methodology of work and become aggressive in work.
cons: Everyone is only responsible for a very small piece of the company. It's hard to get the whole picture. The mechanism inside the company will prevent the information sharing from team members. It's easy to get bored after working few years here.

review_title: The Operation Business is not  as aggressive as what I thought.
pros:
Better salary, just better than the other poor low salary in Taiwan.
Make everything works when decision made.
Convenient facility for basic living, ex: bank, insurance, department store, travel agency, held in specific weekdays.
cons:
Bad training schedule, not that appropriate  for present working.
Always wasting time and resource on projects which is not that organized.
People inside is not off on time, almost not.
Job responsibility is not well disclosure.

pros:
Good business outlook in the near future
Great total compensation in local job market
Relatively young workforce
You will be surrounded by some of the most talented people in the country
cons:
People waste time on things not directly related to business
Poor work/life balance, management expect you to get things done no matter what
Difference of total compensation between people of the same job grade is not significant, even if you outperform most others.
Advancement into manager takes a long time (7+ years), I don't think there is a 'fast-track' system in this company.

review_title: Great place for freshman establish career
pros: Great place to understand the semiconductor manufacturing working process, with good starting salary and bonus as freshman.
cons: As a module engineer, will keep doing the same thing without any rotation and build up your career. Do not stay over 3 years in the same department. The internal transfer process was terrible, some managers do not respect what their employees really want, and HR could not contribute any power during the transfer progress.

pros: The company give a high and competitive salary in Taiwan. Meanwhile, they provide a challenging work in the semiconductor industry. The company is also promising in the near future
cons: The cons of the company might be long working hours (usually 10-12 hour from Monday to Friday) and every month need to work on duty once in the weekend.

pros:
1.Good payment in Taiwan technology industry
2.Aggressive working for most of people 
3.You can always find the right sponsor to solve your problem if you are willing to call for help
4.Most working level engineers are easy to get along with each other.
cons:
1.Highlight culture 
2.long working hour, hard for work-life balance, except support unit
3.High pressure & very fast paced in FAB
4.Some managers EQ not high, bad tempered and mean  
5.Job rotation is  an empty shell, especially in FAB. you have to struggle long time

review_title: Challenging jobs in high pressure, which makes you learn in high speed with acceptable package
pros:
Nice package: about 2x of similar jobs in other companies

Stable career: although competitive to get promotion, but also hard to get fired.
cons:
High pressure: lots of issues coming out every day need to be solved, reviewed, reported. Overtime work is common.

Less respect: it is basically a manufactory with military management style.

No upward KPI review.

pros:
1. A huge company cherishing integrity and commitment
2. CEO, Morris Chang got both ambition and vision 
3. The salary is not bad
4. Can learn new knowledge and skills from work
cons:
1. Hard to be promoted to management level because there are too many senior people  
2. Too many cliche rules, process, and paperwork
3. Long Working hours in general
4. Annual performance review process is not transparent enough

pros: The salary and benifit is quite stable and above average in that area. The environment is good and restaurant is good as well.
cons: Daily heavy work loading makes you have to wrok until mid-night. And daily morning review from manager wll put you in high stress.

pros:
Biggest semiconductor foundry in the world. 
Pride to belong and worked for such a successful company
"The story of a better pay check" than the average companies
Lots of money = lots of respect?
cons:
Military style management. 
Competitve environment leading to selfishness.
Severe hierarchy differentiation
Hard (for me at least) to make loyal or trustworthy friends
Attitude problems: money runs company's culture 
Double personality: money runs people

pros: TSMC is a great company to work for. It is well positioned in its industry and it attracts excellent talent in its fields. People here are smart and hard working, focus on delivering best quality of work.
cons: Work is stressful and hours long. Still a Taiwanese culture dominated company. Less flexibility and open communication. Mostly by top down decisions.

review_title: Great company and good pay with fair work load
pros:
The following are the good part I feel about the company.
For the spend rate in TW, 100k USD is a lot here.

No lay off 
Good pay
Advance technology
Diverse Works
cons:
The work load is very heavy and also very tough, and of course, it is exciting as well.
However, you won't have personal life here. That is the problem.

In the upper management part, here is very politic. Upper managers changed all the time.

Heavy work load
very politic

review_title: High pressure work, mediocre income, poor work/life balance.
pros:
1. Large company makes it easier when dealing with vendor.
2. Mediocre income so that you can maintain life in Taiwan in a slightly easier way.
cons:
1. No training at all (in my department)
2. Poor management caused by political issue.
3. Here you don't strike a balance, cause you are not going to enjoy your work, and you have no life.

review_title: A huge company, keep growing, yet every employee works as a tiny screw.
pros: Huge Company, big challenge of coordinating stuff, learning from doing. Salary is above normal.
cons: time wasting of negotiation between different section, doing none of little benefit work. Take too much time from your life.

review_title: A reasonably good place to work in
pros: one of the world's leading semiconductor company to work for. Good if you're starting out in this industry as the exposure is superb.
cons: the work life balance is practically non existent. be prepared to put in hours of extra work and don't expect to be seen as hardworking as that's the norm in the organization.

pros:
1. good salary 
2. lower entry barrier for graduate 
3. Be a expert in some specific areas 
4. the company's growth is stable and there is no risk to be laid off
cons:
1. unreasonable highlight culture 
2. too many meaningless meeting 
3. too many trivial things to handle 
4. unbalanced work loading 
5. work in a high-pressured and long working environment

review_title: Company with great technology leadership and sound system
pros: Technology leader of chip manufacturing, with good relationships to customers due to special business model which only focus on chip making for customer but not build its own IC products.
cons: A company with plenty of rules to follow due to strict PIP policy. Which is good design for preventing business secret stolen by competitors but it really blocks cross-department cooperation.

review_title: One of the best semiconductor jobs in Taiwan, but the workload is demanding.
pros: They have one of the highest pays in Taiwan for the semiconductor industry. It is also an internationally known company, so workers can lean a lot about the newest technology trends.
cons: With high pay, the workload is not light. It might be necessary to work overtime to get things finished. However, this is how life is in Asia, and generally this has a high CP value in terms of worker benefits.

review_title: Not the best choice, but okay for your first job
pros:
1. Large company
2. Good payment for semiconductor related job
3. Morris is a really nice CEO
4. Nice place for new grad who want to learn the best technology of R&D here in Taiwan
cons:
1. Too many paper work and meeting for a engineer
2. Work hour is too long compare to its payment
3. For engineer in physical design/EDA field, lots of better choice compare to TSMC

job_title: Mixed-signal Design Engineer in Tampa, FL
pros: Seems stable, very low-maintenance, working with latest nodes, good place to learn and then move on, etc.
cons: No career opportunities, the Ottawa office has no vision and thinks too cheap, TSMC does not know how to trust or operate remote offices, the ottawa office is very underwhelming when representing the TSMC brand in Canada.

pros: good to know lots of knowledge from semiconductor. My mentor and buddy always give me lots of help. A very nice company.
cons: I took to many times in learning some basic knowledge. If we can prepare it before going to TSMC, we can have more time to finish our project.

pros: Good salary compare to local salary level.  Stable career path with promotion possibilities. Complete training is provided to new employees with leaders in each stage.
cons: Heavy workload, often required overtime work or work at weekend. Destructive competition can often been seen between colleagues as well as management position.

review_title: Learning how to release my heavy stress.
pros: 1. Good package. 2. Nice team member. 3. Well environment. 4. Learning very fast due to fast path. 5. Learning big company's system.
cons: 1. Long working time. 2. Heavy stress. 3. Far from taipei. 4. Hard to promotion because there are too many staff.

review_title: Great compensation, but a miserable personal life
pros: Proud of being a TSMCer, great place to learn, lots of different filed to work on (R&D, Manufacture, QA, customer service, marketing, etc), great compensation
cons: long working hour, really stressful work load, time pushing, easily to get pressure as unsolve issues are pretty. hardly a personal life

review_title: innovative and highly-stress, but good for entry level engineers interested in CMOS
pros:
1. be able to access leading-edge CMOS technology development
2. enoguh engineering resources to realize your good ideas
3. relatively good salary in Taiwan
cons:
1. high-stress due to tight schedule, especially you have a demending boss (common cases)
2. long working hours (>12hr) 
3. promotion is slow

review_title: A very mediocre place to work
pros:
senior management was great, humble and helpful
accumulated knowledge, invited speakers from famous institutions
top-notch fabs
salary
activities, infrastructure
cons:
motivation is extremely low
horrible information sharing among groups and departments
lots of unnecessary pressure
uber long working hours (14hrs/day regularly, 16 - 18hrs are no exception)
low-level (technical) managers are proud and bossy
company is too large - newcomers have hard time having any impact
bad company culture
constant IP brainwashing
overtime up to 3hrs is considered "daily workload" and is not compensated for

pros: Great place to work with incredibly intelligent, dedicated people at all levels from administrators to executives. A well run company
cons: Challenging to learn TSMC's unique lexicon--it's acronym hell taken to a new level and then some on top of that! Working across business units is a must and not easy to execute--not impossible but the constantly changing landscape makes it something extremely challenging to successfully execute an agenda.

review_title: Core Values: Incompetence, Corruption, Fear & Heirarchy
pros: Brand value due to past success
cons: Its a sinking ship. Tap on its its brand value for next 5 years and then jump off to safety as soon as possible.

review_title: work with senior engineer in designing the FOUP improvement project.
pros: The work environment is very great and summer intern can have chance to take look at different departments, large flexibility.
cons: But full-time engineer needs to spend more time and effort on it. More than 45 hours a per is usual.

review_title: a big company a little engineer
pros: good salary good reputation , you will learn how the big company work and how the good employer treat their employee.
cons: pressure pressure and pressure, you can not sleep well and some of  your colleagues want not help you and leave you alone

review_title: Learned a lot, but not a good place to develop.
pros: As a newly graduated person, it is good to work for tsmc, shanghai. in which you can learned a lot if you like.
cons: Too much personal time consumed by tsmc, can not see your future clearly. every cent you owned is from sweat.

pros: Good wage. Reasonable workload. The company can provide a very clear career path for all employees. The benefit is above average.
cons: There is no compensation for the overtime. Working environment is not so ideal for female employee. The annual leave provided is not enough.

pros: Employees welfare is given great importance. Even at times of economic crisis employees were furloughed but not fired.  Opportunity to do great work in some of the teams.
cons: Rigid job grade structure. Managers seemed to care more about time spent on job rather than quality of work. Did not seem to reward initiative from junior employees.

review_title: Where there is light, there is shadow.
pros:
1. Employees here has similar characteristic and react to requirement with SOP. (on the other side it's lack of diversity) 
2. Policy follower, take top down orders without doubt.
3. Communication speed is the key
cons:
1. Overtime working or working on weekend is normal (And it's a cultural thing cause the management preference)
2. Very strict information protection policy, can't deal alot of private issue during work hours

pros:
good salary, comparing with other semi companies in Taiwan.
reputations are also good, proud to work there.
free parking space.
cons:
not so much position u can advance to.
need a long time to get to the management level.
Hsinchu is boring, comparing to Taipei.

pros: Clear goals,work with smart persons and higher wages.Many opportunities to experience IC manufacture art from design to chip ,up-to-date process,methodology and technology with high volumn production.
cons: Everyone 's time is 24 hrs a day. Time and energy is limited but still need to generate your good result in time.Not easy to have good balance among work,family,health and future.

pros: TSMC is a "famous" company in Taiwan and it does make a lot of profit by making IC chips!
cons: Process Integration Engineers are 24/7 on call. 80% of engineers get off work at 8:30pm~10:00pm which means work life are unbalanced. We have a fast turnover rate. In my team, there are 4 engineers. The oldest engineer is 33 years old and my boss is 37 years old.

review_title: A great company ,with various complex duties
pros:
leading edge company in mass production of semiconductor wafer manufacturing industry,
learn a lot of techniques and views in engineering field,
a lot of great and awesome people work there , learn from them and work with those brilliant people is very great.
cons:
Long , very long work time , you can not balance your life and work ,
every one in there

review_title: Good Salary. Severe culture. Hugh loading difference between departments
pros: Above level annual total salary, smart people and data-based work culture
cons: Conservative environment, value more on not to make mistake than do some thing good; imbalance between life and work; you will face difficult situation under mutually contradictory KPI which drives people focus on defending than cooperating.

review_title: Semiconductor manufacturing is that kind of technology that you always feel it's far from your life.
pros: Tsmc is an international, big, and stable company. If you want to work in a company with good salary, welfare, and rules, Tsmc is a choice you could make.
cons:
1) Long work hours and high work stress.
2) Shift work might affect health.
3) Last but not least, Hsin-chu is a boring city.

review_title: Great experience working with talented people.
pros: The people at TSMC were very motivated and hardworking. The culture of the company is very united and everyone that works there is very passionate about what TSMC does. Facebook, gmail, and other "distracting" websites are blocked to promote efficiency.
cons: There are very strict rules regarding usage of phones/computers etc. The work environment seems very stressful and the hours are very long.

pros: The company invests large sector of capital into research and development. Good place for technology development, since sufficient resources are available.
cons: The management emphasize very much on personal performance. Some people use 'strategies' to obtain credits. But the 'strategies' can be immoral. The environment is quite political.

pros: Good money / profit sharing
cons:
1> Managers are mostly ignorant, but treated like God
2> No opportunity of knowledge growth
3> No industry like culture, it's much like academics, a bunch of people just following their manager's directions (as if Professor) for money (as if grade)

review_title: 4 yield inline defect control and bright field defect inspection tool hands on / managing experience.
pros: The money is okay, basically this company obey the laws and government regulations.
cons: No life. Very pushing (unreasonable request) and they will ask you to do so to others if they think it's needed.

pros: Competitive Salary, Enrich knowledge in Semiconductor manufacturing, Self-motivation, good working environment, keep high competition in advanced process technology ...etc
cons: Promotion too slow in R&D if you don't own PhD degree, long working hours, not 100% international company because there are still some of managers  keep past management style ...etc

pros: Very interesting technical work, good salary, nice working environment. TSMC is the leader in market share and process technology in the foundry sector, so the job was very stable in that sense.
cons: Old-fashioned company culture, very hierarchical, completely non-transparent promotion procedure. None of the benefits of a modern employer. Focus on financial incentives, no real interest in developing human resources.

pros: Good salary. Stable. Usually does not kick people out.
cons: You can bring almost nothing electronic inside. In addition, the company blocks out lots of web sites that have no obvious security concerns.

pros: interesting technologies, secure place to wait for CPP, salary good if PhD or has 20 years more experience.
cons: core hours have only starting time, no career path to hear about , benefits are not so good. Very old peoples

pros:
1. Very competitive salary for a software engineer in Taiwan
2. Large company with lots of smart people in it.
cons:
1. use relatively stable(old) technology for project development
2. most of the requirement are internal facing application, rather than customer facing products( which is understandable since Its a manufacturer)

pros:
Profitable company. 
Competitive salary compared with the other company in Taiwan
Lot Benefits for employees
cons:
Working hour is long, but it depends on what department you are working for.
The company is too large so sometimes you can not get the whole picture of one project.
The security policy is quite annoying for some of the work

pros: TSMC is a good company with a lot of challenges and opportunities. I learned a lot of technical and management skills when I worked in this company.
cons: You cannot bring your smart phone into your working area! You cannot bring your smart phone into your working area! You cannot bring your smart phone into your working area!

review_title: Tech savvy, but not really business smart
pros: Execution, execution and execution; This company,except for the CEO, is excellent at almost everything it does as long as you do not ask them about "Strategy".  There is only one strategist in this company.  By the way, work-life balance is getting better
cons: Almost sucks on anything that is not foundry.

pros: Except the money,work at TSMC can learned about presentation speeches or repart, managements, scheduled,KPI, CIP...etc , team work and cross department co-work ,
cons: Scheduled always have to pull in, so co-work with other departments is very important, and how to negotiation with supervisor the schedule is also an challenge

pros:
Intensive and comprehensive training program
TSMC is the most valuable semi-conductor company in the world, therefore it has biggest platform for employees to bring their talent in play.
cons: the defensive strategy of TSMC is to prevent the business secret to spread out to its competitors, therefore electronic device regulation is very strict.

pros:
free anual body checkup
clubs/ free gym access for employees 
child care service
interesting speakers to inspire employees
tsmc pays 50% for some courses
cons: the actual workplace environment for the older buildings is very depressing.

review_title: Good company for the first job from school
pros: The trainning is good. Will have very detaided working style for your next job. Good pay in Taiwan. Easy to find a good job after you leave the company.
cons: Not too much fun, cannot have balance between life and family. Lack of manaragement opening and hard to be permoted.

review_title: Good company with strong business. Expanding fast and willing to invest in R&D and Fab capacity.
pros: Good payment and benefits. Everyone works together toward an agreed gaol for doing things successfully.
cons: Fewer vacancies for high level managers. The company loves to hire high level (director or above) managers from outside.

review_title: Good Learning Experience for fresh graduates
pros: A lot of responsibility to do important projects, work independently and explore different areas. Very good location.
cons: Long working hours during tapeout, short product cycles, shortage of manpower, lack of efficient training program for newcomers.

pros:
great compensation.
simple business model, company focus on technology leadership, manufacturing efficiency, and fulfill customer demand.
cons: value trap for people with higher capacity.

pros: Well known company with good reputation. Normal pay, great bonus, nice environment, most of the management are smart and with management skills

don't tell the truth, tell what the management wants to hear. Very few chance to get prompt in this giant company

review_title: Stressful environment yet learn a lot

pros: Relative higher salary among Taiwan tech companies.
cons: Bad living environment in Hsinchu. Extreme care about intellectual property which causes inconvenience for employees. Hard to achieve work-life balance (common situation in Taiwan tech companies though). Less promising business outlook in a long run.

pros: Leading semiconductor manufacturing company with strong culture in innovation. Senior management is quite strong. Based in Taiwan, but recently start to raise its visibility in China.
cons: In terms of technology, TSMC is still following footsteps of Intel. TSMC's main strength is in cost-down and very carefully crafted expansion strategies; not in ground-breaking innovation.

pros: High salary and welfare. Good opportunities for people who want to broaden their knowledge in semiconductor area.

pros: Good training and nice co-workers. Process control is the best in the world.

review_title: TSMC provides competitive salary because of long working hours

pros: I worked for the HQ of TSMC which locates in Hsinchu, Taiwan. The working environment is better than most of the companies in Taiwan because of the salary.

review_title: Good salary but no life balance

NO work-life balance even works are finished. You are required to stay in the office until at least 8pm.

pros: TSMC brand name & the latest technology node to work.

pros: the company has a grown-up business, and almost dominate at this field. the extra benefit is above the general company. The tier 1 company in Taiwan.

review_title: The longer you stay, the less chance you can get

pros: good pay compared to other company in Taiwan;everyone is reponsible for a small area, hard to get an overview to the industry.

pros: Good salary. Technology leader. Excellent project execution. Winner takes all. Some nice people are there.

pros: The employees in Taiwan get a satisfied annual pay compared to other companies and have the opportunity to improve skills.
